text: regreSSHion: Remote unauthenticated code execution in OpenSSH server. Race condition in signal handler allows RCE on glibc-based Linux. Affects OpenSSH 8.5p1 through 9.7p1.
OpenSSH ssh-agent remote code execution via PKCS#11 provider. Forwarded agent socket can be exploited for arbitrary code execution on the client.
PwnKit: Local privilege escalation in polkit pkexec. Memory corruption in command-line argument handling allows any unprivileged user to gain root.
Sudo privilege escalation via sudoedit. Arbitrary file write by exploiting user-provided environment variables in sudoedit.
Baron Samedit: Heap-based buffer overflow in sudo. Allows any local user to gain root privileges without authentication via sudoedit -s.
XZ Utils backdoor. Malicious code injected into xz compression library versions 5.6.0 and 5.6.1, enabling SSH authentication bypass on affected systems.
Citrix Bleed: Information disclosure in Citrix NetScaler. Allows session token theft and unauthorized access without credentials.

SSH brute force attacks commonly originate from botnets using credential stuffing. Typical pattern: 5-50 attempts/minute from single IP, targeting root/admin/deploy accounts. Often precedes lateral movement.

Port scanning reconnaissance typically targets common service ports (22, 80, 443, 3306, 5432, 6379, 27017). Nmap SYN scans from external IPs indicate pre-attack probing. Often followed by exploitation within 24-48 hours.

Data exfiltration via SCP/SFTP to external IPs. Attackers stage data in /tmp, compress with tar/gzip, then transfer. Transfers >100MB to non-corporate IPs are high-confidence indicators of exfiltration.
Lateral movement via SSH key reuse. After compromising one host, attackers use stolen SSH keys to pivot to internal servers. Internal-to-internal SSH on non-standard ports is a strong indicator.
Privilege escalation via sudo misconfiguration. Attackers exploit NOPASSWD entries, wildcard injection in sudoers, or known sudo CVEs to gain root access after initial foothold.
Living-off-the-land techniques using standard tools: curl/wget for C2, crontab for persistence, netcat for reverse shells. These bypass signature-based detection by using legitimate binaries.
Leaky Vessels: Container escape vulnerability in runc. Allows attackers to break out of container isolation and access the host filesystem.
Database exfiltration pattern: mysqldump or pg_dump to local file, followed by compression and SCP to external IP. Often occurs during off-hours to avoid detection.
F5 BIG-IP authentication bypass. Remote unauthenticated attacker can execute arbitrary system commands via the management port.
